abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for Mexico renewable energy for
            agriculture project were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the borrower
            performance was satisfactory. Lessons learned from the
            project: In order to ensure the optimal impact of
            interventions, it was essential that the principal project
            implementing agency was related to the agriculture sector in
            order that it could promote productive uses of the energy.
            In order to ensure the optimal impact of interventions, it
            became clear during implementation that it was essential to
            consider the livelihood consequences that will occur through
            provision of renewable energy and to integrate this into all
            components, including through investing in improving
            productive processes. It is important to ensure that
            dissemination is considered carefully in project design.
            Subprojects must be supported by co-financing from
            beneficiaries. For renewable energy investments to have a
            high impact and broad replication, an effective financing
            scheme is very important and this will most likely have to
            involve subsidized financing. Close monitoring and tracking
            of technical assistance and its results through innovative
            use of the internet and GIS can help greatly to evaluate the
            success of activities and to modify and optimize them.
